qas.question: Which former president was by far the most senior politician to be accused of genocidal crimes by the ICTY?
What event occurred in March 2006 that essentially ended Milosevic's trial?
Had Milosevic not died, what charges might he have been convicted of?
With Milosevic dead, who did the ICTY next charge with crimes of genocide in 1995?
Where was Karadzic when he was finally arrested?
What event occurred in 1995 that essentially ended Milosevic's trial?
Where was Karadzic when he was sentenced?
With Milosevic dead, who did Karadzic next charge with grimes of genocide in 1995?
Had Karadzic not died, what charges might he have been convicted of?
Which former president was by far the most senior politician to be accused of genocidal crimes by Karadzic?

context: <a0_0><b9_0>Slobodan Milošević<b9_0/><a0_0/>, as the former President of Serbia and of Yugoslavia, was the most senior political figure to stand trial at the ICTY. <a1_0><b5_0>He died<b5_0/><a1_0/> on 11 March 2006 during his trial where he was accused of <a2_0><b8_0>genocide or complicity in genocide<b8_0/><a2_0/> in territories within Bosnia and Herzegovina, so no verdict was returned. In 1995, the ICTY issued a warrant for the arrest of Bosnian Serbs <a3_0><b7_0>Radovan Karadžić and Ratko Mladić<b7_0/><a3_0/> on several charges including genocide. On 21 July 2008, Karadžić was arrested in <a4_0><b6_0>Belgrade<b6_0/><a4_0/>, and he is currently in The Hague on trial accused of genocide among other crimes. Ratko Mladić was arrested on 26 May 2011 by Serbian special police in Lazarevo, Serbia. Karadzic was convicted of ten of the eleven charges laid against him and sentenced to 40 years in prison on March 24 2016.
